Standard approach involves hormone replacement therapy, primarily with gonadotropins or low-dose estrogen to induce pubertal development, considering neurodevelopmental timeline, with psychosocial support. The ocular symptoms, particularly visual disturbances, require further ophthalmic evaluation to exclude intracranial causes such as intracranial mass, which might necessitate urgent neuroimaging. Lifestyle and psychological support are vital. Regular follow-up with endocrinology and ophthalmology is essential. Clear communication with a patient who may be confused or overwhelmed should focus on easing understanding, addressing worries, and involving family for support. Referrals to neurology or ophthalmology are warranted promptly if neurological signs persist or worsen.
